titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts and Culture Unit (MAC), Office Files of Elizabeth Richards
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts and Culture Unit (MAC), Office Files of Elizabeth Richards FA505

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-01 01:07:32 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts and Culture Unit (MAC), Office Files of Elizabeth Richards

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the files Elizabeth "Betsy" Richards created when she worked as a Program Officer in the Ford Foundation's Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC). The files document her managing the Foundation's grant portfolio on Indigenous Knowledge and Expressive Culture. The collection is comprised of one series of subject files.

The collection documents the Ford Foundation's program activities for expanding the field of Native American arts and culture through increased philanthropy and capacity building, support to different Native American arts and culture organizations in a variety of genres and areas, intellectual property rights, and tribal education. Several files show a global consideration of Indigenous peoples in addition to supporting Native American tribes, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.

Common material formats found throughout the collection include correspondence, memos, notes, drafts, reports, articles, proposals, grant action records, and publications. There are also a few digital media items in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of one series.
Original order was maintained as much as possible.
The collection arrangement is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in three accessions between 2019 and 2021 and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2019:187, 2020:028, and 2021:135.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the subject files Elizabeth "Betsy" Richards created and maintained when she worked as a Program officer in the Ford Foundation's Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF), Media, Arts, and Culture unit (MAC). Richards' subject files document her activities managing the Foundation's grant portfolio on Indigenous Knowledge and Expressive Culture.

The series provides insight into the development, objectives, activities, and products of the Ford Foundation's programming for Native American arts and culture in the 2000s. Richards' Program Officer Memo drafts and notes show her suggestion to name the grant portfolio Indigenous Knowledge and Expressive Culture to better represent concepts used by Indigenous Peoples. These documents also outline the initiatives of the portfolio â€“ Strengthening the Field of Native American Arts and Culture and Advancing the Dialogue on Native American Arts in Society. Other records show the Foundation's activities for gathering and analyzing data related to past grants for Native American issues.

Files show the work of internal Ford Foundation groups and projects like the Committee on Indigenous Peoples (CIP) and IllumiNation. CIP examined the Foundation's grantmaking for Indigenous Peoples throughout the world and IllumiNation sought to expand philanthropy for Native American arts and culture.

Other files show the grant support the Ford Foundation gave to various Native American arts and culture organizations in theater, museums, radio, music, and basketmaking. Grantees were also interested in intellectual property rights and tribal education for Native American youth. Many of the files are named after grantees of Richards' portfolio.
There are also some files which document the Ford Foundation's broader work in arts and culture, especially its activities for marginalized communities like African Americans and Arab Americans.
